entry.title: Project Report
entry.summary:
In this notebook, you'll sumarize your finding for the class presentation.

The class presentation will use this notebook in slide mode, as I do during lecture time.

You'll need to download the following zip file, unzip it, and run the following notebook install-support.ipynb to install the slide capabilities.

The notebook notebook-slideshow-example.ipynb will give you examples on how to use slides within the iPython notebook.

You should also write this notebook so that you can convert it nicely into a pdf document using the commands

ipython nbconvert NB4_report.pynb --to latex
pdflatex NB4_report.tex

See here for further references on how to do that.

In this notebook, you'll

  • describe your problem as stated in the propectus

  • comment on your data sources, on their format, on the difficulties to get them

  • present the main challenge you encountered

  • present your finding in the form of expresive graphics

Be sure to include an introduction section motivating your visualizations, with a description of the substantive context and why it is interesting.

Cite the source of the data and any other references that you used in carrying out your project.

Team members responsible for this notebook:

List the team members contributing to this notebook, along with their responsabilities:

  • team member 1 name: team member 1 responsabilities
  • team member 2 name: team member 2 responsabilities
  • etc.

I advise you to work at least in pairs for each project notebook, as you did for the homework assignments. Of course, all team members may participate to each notebook.

entry.title: Data Analysis
entry.summary:
In this notebook, you'll perform the actual analysis of the data stored in the directory

./data/cleaned

If the data is not ready yet (e.g. the other members of the team in charge of cleaning the data are not done yet), you may want to simulate cleaned data in the form you want them to be in order to perform the analysis. This may also help you data cleaning team to come up with the rigth data frame. If you choose to do so, store your simulated data into the directory

./data/simulated

Having performed analysis of simulated data may help you with the analysis of the actual data, since you will be able to notice deviations between the real and simulated data, which may be worth explaining and investigating further.

The graphics your going to produce as a result of your analysis should be store in the directory:

./visualization

Team members responsible for this notebook:

List the team members contributing to this notebook, along with their responsabilities:

  • team member 1 name: team member 1 responsabilities
  • team member 2 name: team member 2 responsabilities
  • etc.

I advise you to work at least in pairs for each project notebook, as you did for the homework assignments. Of course, all team members may participate to each notebook.

Load R Magic¶

In [1]: 
%load_ext rmagic
In [2]: 
%%R
library("zoo")


Attaching package: ‘zoo’

The following objects are masked from ‘package:base’:

    as.Date, as.Date.numeric

Loading Data¶

In [3]: 
%%R
IT = read.zoo("../data/cleaned/IT.csv", sep = ",", header = TRUE, format = "%Y-%m-%d")
apple = ts(IT$Apple, f=365)

Time Series Analysis¶

Time Plot Function¶

In [4]: 
%%R
timeplotfunction = function(x, color, ylim){
    plot(x, type="l", col=color, xlab="Year", ylab="Adj. Close Price", main="Time Plot of IT Stock", ylim=ylim)
    }

IT Stock Time Plot¶

In [28]: 
%%R
# Time Plot
jpeg('../visualizations/TS_IT.jpg')
timeplotfunction(apple, "red", c(0:500))
par(new=TRUE)
timeplotfunction(IT$Google, "orange", c(0:500))
par(new=TRUE)
timeplotfunction(IT$Amazon, "yellow", c(0:500))
par(new=TRUE)
timeplotfunction(IT$Microsoft, "green", c(0:500))
par(new=TRUE)
timeplotfunction(IT$HP, "blue", c(0:500))

# Legend
legend('topleft', colnames(IT) , lty=1, col=c('red', 'orange', 'yellow',' green', 'blue'), bty='n')
dev.off()

Error in plot.window(xlim, ylim, log, ...) : invalid 'ylim' value
In [6]: 
from IPython.display import Image
Image(filename='../visualizations/TS_IT.jpg')
Out[6]:
In [7]: 
%%R
# Seasonal Decompostion
jpeg('../visualizations/Apple_Seasonal_Decomp.jpg')
decomp_aapl = stl(ts(IT$Apple, frequency=365), s.window="periodic", robust=TRUE)
plot(decomp_aapl, col='red', main="Apple Seasonal Decomposition")
dev.off()
In [8]: 
from IPython.display import Image
Image(filename='../visualizations/Apple_Seasonal_Decomp.jpg')
Out[8]:

http://leve.rs/blog/how-to-correctly-forecast-seasonal-marketing-trends-with-stl/

Seasonal Differencing¶

In [9]: 
%%R
jpeg('../visualizations/Apple_Seasonal_Differencing.jpg')
# Seasonal Differencing
appleseasonaldiff = diff(IT$Apple, lag=365)
plot(appleseasonaldiff, type="l", col="red", xlab="Year", ylab="Adj. Close Price", main="Apple Seasonal Differencing")
dev.off()

jpeg('../visualizations/Apple_Seasonal_Trend_Differencing.jpg')
# Seasonal & 1st Trend Differencing
appletrenddiff1 = diff(appleseasonaldiff)
plot(appletrenddiff1, type="l", col="red", xlab="Year", ylab="Adj. Close Price", main="Apple Seasonal & 1st Differencing")
dev.off()
In [10]: 
from IPython.display import Image
Image(filename='../visualizations/Apple_Seasonal_Differencing.jpg')
Out[10]:
In [11]: 
from IPython.display import Image
Image(filename='../visualizations/Apple_Seasonal_Trend_Differencing.jpg')
Out[11]:

Load Library "FORECAST"¶

In [12]: 
%%R
#install.packages("forecast")
library("forecast")

Loading required package: timeDate
This is forecast 5.3
In [13]: 
%%R
# Time Series Display
jpeg('../visualizations/Apple_TS_Display.jpg')
tsdisplay(appletrenddiff1, main="Trend Time Series")
dev.off()
In [14]: 
from IPython.display import Image
Image(filename='../visualizations/Apple_TS_Display.jpg')
Out[14]:

Finding Auto ARIMA¶

In [15]: 
%%R
# Auto
print(auto.arima(IT$Apple))

ARIMA(3,1,0) with drift

      -0.0518  -0.0924  0.0622  0.1820
s.e.   0.0324   0.0448  0.0480  0.1343

sigma^2 estimated as 46.25:  log likelihood=-3931.99
AIC=7873.97   AICc=7874   BIC=7902.43

Function for Fitting Seasonal with ARIMA(3,1,0)¶

In [24]: 
%%R
# Fitting Seasonal with ARIMA(3,1,0)
total_fit_apple = function(x){
  arima(IT$Apple, order=c(3,1,0), seasonal=list(order=x, period=365))
}

entry.title: Data Cleaning
entry.summary:
In this notebook, you'll

  • load the raw data into R or Pandas dataframe from the ./data/raw directory using the functions and classes (written during the data gathering phase) in the ./script directory

  • perform visual exploration on your data variables to detect anomalies, errors, outliers, interesting features etc.

  • clean categorical and quantitative variables (by removing observations and variables with too many missing values, by consolidating categorical variables, by selecting an appropriate subset of variables and observations for later analysis, etc.)

  • save the cleaned data into csv files in the ./data/cleaned directory

  • save interesting graphics you obtained during visual exploration into the ./visualiation directory

Team members responsible for this notebook:

List the team members contributing to this notebook, along with their responsabilities:

  • team member 1 Hui, Man Kin (Ken): Transform the Data to Time Series, and Gathering the Data by Category
  • team member 2 name: team member 2 responsabilities
  • etc.

I advise you to work at least in pairs for each project notebook, as you did for the homework assignments. Of course, all team members may participate to each notebook.

R Magic¶

In [13]: 
# Loading R Magic
%load_ext rmagic

The rmagic extension is already loaded. To reload it, use:
  %reload_ext rmagic

Import Datetime & Pandas¶

In [14]: 
# Import Datetime & Pandas
import datetime
import pandas as pd
import pandas.io.data
from pandas import Series, DataFrame

Loading Data to Panda¶

In [35]: 
aapl = pd.read_csv('../data/raw/aapl.csv', index_col='Date')
googl = pd.read_csv('../data/raw/googl.csv', index_col='Date')
amzn = pd.read_csv('../data/raw/amzn.csv', index_col='Date')
msft = pd.read_csv('../data/raw/msft.csv', index_col='Date')
hp = pd.read_csv('../data/raw/hp.csv', index_col='Date')

Making Daily Data - Adj Close Price¶

In [36]: 
# Making Daily Adjust Close Price
daapl = pd.DataFrame(aapl)[['Adj Close']]
dgoogl = pd.DataFrame(googl)[['Adj Close']]
damzn = pd.DataFrame(amzn)[['Adj Close']]
dmsft = pd.DataFrame(msft)[['Adj Close']]
dhp = pd.DataFrame(hp)[['Adj Close']]

# Saving to CSV
daapl.to_csv('../data/cleaned/daapl.csv')
dgoogl.to_csv('../data/cleaned/dgoogl.csv')
damzn.to_csv('../data/cleaned/damzn.csv')
dmsft.to_csv('../data/cleaned/dmsft.csv')
dhp.to_csv('../data/cleaned/dhp.csv')

Loading Raw Data to R¶

In [95]: 
%%R
# Loading Raw Data
aapl = read.csv("../data/raw/aapl.csv")
googl = read.csv("../data/raw/googl.csv")
amzn = read.csv("../data/raw/amzn.csv")
msft = read.csv("../data/raw/msft.csv")
hp = read.csv("../data/raw/hp.csv")

Making Weekly Data - Adj Close Price¶

Function for Making Weekly Data¶

In [96]: 
%%R
weeklydata = function(x){
    a = matrix(x$Adj.Close,7)
    b = colMeans(a)
    wweek = c(1:length(b))
    c = data.frame(wweek, b)
    colnames(c) = c("Week", "Adj Close")
    c}

Making Weekly Data¶

In [97]: 
%%R
# Making Weekly Data
waapl = weeklydata(aapl)
wgoogl = weeklydata(googl)
wamzn = weeklydata(amzn)
wmsft = weeklydata(msft)
whp = weeklydata(hp)

Saving Weekly Data¶

In [106]: 
%%R
# Saving to CSV
write.csv(file='../data/cleaned/waapl.csv', x=waapl, row.names=FALSE)
write.csv(file='../data/cleaned/wgoogl.csv', x=wgoogl, row.names=FALSE)
write.csv(file='../data/cleaned/wamzn.csv', x=wamzn, row.names=FALSE)
write.csv(file='../data/cleaned/wmsft.csv', x=wmsft, row.names=FALSE)
write.csv(file='../data/cleaned/whp.csv', x=whp, row.names=FALSE)

Making Category Data - Adj. Close Price¶

Loading Daily Data to R¶

In [141]: 
%%R
# Loading Raw Data
daapl = read.csv("../data/cleaned/daapl.csv")
dgoogl = read.csv("../data/cleaned/dgoogl.csv")
damzn = read.csv("../data/cleaned/damzn.csv")
dmsft = read.csv("../data/cleaned/dmsft.csv")
dhp = read.csv("../data/cleaned/dhp.csv")

Combine Adjust Close Price Function¶

In [145]: 
%%R
# Function
adjclosecombine = function(a, b, c, d, e){
    data.frame(a$Date, a$"Adj.Close", b$"Adj.Close", c$"Adj.Close", d$"Adj.Close", e$"Adj.Close")
}

Dataframe by Category¶

In [148]: 
%%R
# Making IT Stock Data
IT = adjclosecombine(aapl, googl, amzn, msft, hp)
colnames(IT) = c("Date", "Apple", "Google", "Amazon", "Microsoft", "HP")
write.csv(file='../data/cleaned/IT.csv', x=IT, row.names=FALSE)

Function for Displaying Weekly Data¶

In []: 
# Function for Displaying Weekly Data
def wdisplay(x):
    print('Weekly Data - ' + x)
    !head ../data/cleaned/daapl.csv
    print('')

Using R Library "ZOO"¶

In [15]: 
%%R
# Install
#install.packages("zoo")
library("zoo")
In [42]: 
%%R
# Loading Raw Data
aapl = read.zoo("../data/raw/aapl.csv", sep = ",", header = TRUE, format = "%Y-%m-%d")
googl = read.zoo("../data/raw/googl.csv", sep = ",", header = TRUE, format = "%Y-%m-%d")
amzn = read.zoo("../data/raw/amzn.csv", sep = ",", header = TRUE, format = "%Y-%m-%d")
msft = read.zoo("../data/raw/msft.csv", sep = ",", header = TRUE, format = "%Y-%m-%d")
hp = read.zoo("../data/raw/hp.csv", sep = ",", header = TRUE, format = "%Y-%m-%d")
In [49]: 
%%R
# Converting to Matrix
maapl = matrix(aapl$Adj.Close,7)
mgoogl = matrix(googl$Adj.Close,7)
mamzn = matrix(amzn$Adj.Close,7)
mmsft = matrix(msft$Adj.Close,7)
mhp = matrix(hp$Adj.Close,7)

# Take Mean (by Weekly)
waaplt = colMeans(maapl)
wgooglt = colMeans(mgoogl)
wamznt = colMeans(mamzn)
wmsftt = colMeans(mmsft)
whpt = colMeans(mhp)

# Convert DataFrame
wweek = c(1:length(waaplt))
waapl = data.frame(wweek, waaplt)
wgoogl = data.frame(wweek, wgooglt)
wamzn = data.frame(wweek, wamznt)
wmsft = data.frame(wweek, wmsftt)
whp = data.frame(wweek, whpt)

# Changing Column Names
colnames(waapl) = c("Week", "Adj Close")
colnames(wgoogl) = c("Week", "Adj Close")
colnames(wamzn) = c("Week", "Adj Close")
colnames(wmsft) = c("Week", "Adj Close")
colnames(whp) = c("Week", "Adj Close")

# Saving to CSV
write.csv(file='../data/raw/waapl.csv', x=waapl)
write.csv(file='../data/raw/wgoogl.csv', x=wgoogl)
write.csv(file='../data/raw/wamzn.csv', x=wamzn)
write.csv(file='../data/raw/wmsft.csv', x=wmsft)
write.csv(file='../data/raw/whp.csv', x=whp)

Example¶

Here I'll load the plant data in xml format into a R data frame using the

create_df_from_plant_xml(file)

function contained in the R script

    ./script/plant_df-R
In [4]: 
%load_ext rmagic

The rmagic extension is already loaded. To reload it, use:
  %reload_ext rmagic

To load the function into a R cell, one needs to use the

source(R_script_file)

command in R, which works in a similar way as the

import module

command in Python:

In [5]: 
%%R
source('./script/plant_df-R')

Now, we can create a data frame directly from the XML file using the functin contained in the scrip above.

If you wish to perform the cleaning using Pandas data frames instead of R data frames, one make the R data frame available to Python cells by using the R magic command:

%%R -d df_name

To know more on how to pass variables back and forth between R and Python cells, please have a look at the notebook here.

In [7]: 
%%R -d data

library(XML)

data = create_df_from_plant_xml('./data/raw/plant.xml')

Now let's load our data into a Pandas data frame:

In [8]: 
from pandas import DataFrame

df = DataFrame(data)
df.head()

entry.title: Data Gathering
entry.summary:
In this notebook, you'll

  • create the directory structure for your project
  • download the raw data for your project
  • write functions and classes to transform raw data (e.g in XML, jason, etc.) into data frames
  • explain what your are doing

Team Members Responsible for This Notebook:

List the team members contributing to this notebook, along with their responsabilities:

  • Team Member 1 Hui, Man Kin (Ken): Write Code for Downloading Data from API
  • Team Member 2 name: team member 2 responsabilities
  • etc.

I advise you to work at least in pairs for each project notebook, as you did for the homework assignments. Of course, all team members may participate to each notebook.

Downloading Data¶

Import Datetime & Pandas¶

In [165]: 
# Import Datetime & Pandas
import datetime
import pandas as pd
import pandas.io.data
from pandas import Series, DataFrame

Function for Downloading Raw Data from Yahoo API¶

In [174]: 
# Function for Downloading Raw Data from Yahoo API
def download(a):
    return(pd.io.data.get_data_yahoo(a,
                                     start = datetime.datetime(2008, 3, 31),
                                     end = datetime.datetime(2014, 3, 31)))

Downloading Raw Data¶

In [175]: 
# Downloading Raw Data
aapl = download('AAPL')
googl = download('GOOGL')
amzn = download('AMZN')
msft = download('MSFT')
hp = download('HP')

Saving Raw Data to CSV File¶

In [176]: 
# Saving to CSV
aapl.to_csv('../data/raw/aapl.csv')
googl.to_csv('../data/raw/googl.csv')
amzn.to_csv('../data/raw/amzn.csv')
msft.to_csv('../data/raw/msft.csv')
hp.to_csv('../data/raw/hp.csv')

    print('Raw Data - ' + x)

Making Weekly Data by Matrix¶










In [77]:





%%R
# Converting to Matrix
maapl = matrix(aapl$Adj.Close,7)
mgoogl = matrix(googl$Adj.Close,7)
mamzn = matrix(amzn$Adj.Close,7)
mmsft = matrix(msft$Adj.Close,7)
mhp = matrix(hp$Adj.Close,7)

# Take Mean (by Weekly)
waaplt = colMeans(maapl)
wgooglt = colMeans(mgoogl)
wamznt = colMeans(mamzn)
wmsftt = colMeans(mmsft)
whpt = colMeans(mhp)

# Convert DataFrame
wweek = c(1:length(waaplt))
waapl = data.frame(wweek, waaplt)
wgoogl = data.frame(wweek, wgooglt)
wamzn = data.frame(wweek, wamznt)
wmsft = data.frame(wweek, wmsftt)
whp = data.frame(wweek, whpt)

# Changing Column Names
colnames(waapl) = c("Week", "Adj Close")
colnames(wgoogl) = c("Week", "Adj Close")
colnames(wamzn) = c("Week", "Adj Close")
colnames(wmsft) = c("Week", "Adj Close")
colnames(whp) = c("Week", "Adj Close")

# Saving to CSV
write.csv(file='../data/raw/waapl.csv', x=waapl)
write.csv(file='../data/raw/wgoogl.csv', x=wgoogl)
write.csv(file='../data/raw/wamzn.csv', x=wamzn)
write.csv(file='../data/raw/wmsft.csv', x=wmsft)
write.csv(file='../data/raw/whp.csv', x=whp)

Downloading and displaying raw data¶







In this example, I am using R. You want to use Python instead.









In [2]:





%load_ext rmagic













TO DO: list sources, display data sample, explain data content, etc.






We now download an XML source containing plant data, and display an typical plant entry, represented as a XML node:









In [6]:





%%R
library(XML)
plant_url  =  'http://www.stat.berkeley.edu/classes/s133/data/plant_catalog.xml'
plant_file = './data/raw/plant.xml'

download.file(plant_url, plant_file, method="curl")

xml_doc   = xmlParse(plant_file)
root_node = xmlRoot(xml_doc)

plant_nodes = xmlChildren(root_node)
print(plant_nodes[[1]])

Loading raw data into data frames¶







The dataframe column labels are the tags of the XML nodes, contained in the plant XML nodes:









In [7]:





%%R
column_names = names(plant_nodes[[1]])
cat(column_names)





















COMMON BOTANICAL ZONE LIGHT PRICE AVAILABILITY


















Given a column name, we create a data frame column containing the column values:









In [11]:





%%R
common_tag = column_names[1]

get_value = function(plant_node, tag) xmlValue(plant_node[[tag]])
    
common_column = sapply(plant_nodes, get_value, common_tag)
    
cat(common_column)





















Bloodroot Columbine Marsh Marigold Cowslip Dutchman's-Breeches Ginger, Wild Hepatica Liverleaf Jack-In-The-Pulpit Mayapple Phlox, Woodland Phlox, Blue Spring-Beauty Trillium Wake Robin Violet, Dog-Tooth Trout Lily Adder's-Tongue Anemone Grecian Windflower Bee Balm Bergamot Black-Eyed Susan Buttercup Crowfoot Butterfly Weed Cinquefoil Primrose Gentian Blue Gentian Jacob's Ladder Greek Valerian California Poppy Shooting Star Snakeroot Cardinal Flower


















We package the code above into a function that creates the data frame column corresponding from a tag name and a list of plant nodes:









In [12]:





%%R
get_column = function(tag, plants) sapply(plants, get_value, tag)
    
cat((get_column('COMMON', plant_nodes)))





















Bloodroot Columbine Marsh Marigold Cowslip Dutchman's-Breeches Ginger, Wild Hepatica Liverleaf Jack-In-The-Pulpit Mayapple Phlox, Woodland Phlox, Blue Spring-Beauty Trillium Wake Robin Violet, Dog-Tooth Trout Lily Adder's-Tongue Anemone Grecian Windflower Bee Balm Bergamot Black-Eyed Susan Buttercup Crowfoot Butterfly Weed Cinquefoil Primrose Gentian Blue Gentian Jacob's Ladder Greek Valerian California Poppy Shooting Star Snakeroot Cardinal Flower


















We are now ready to retrieve all the columns of our data frame into a list of vectors, which we will use to construct our data frame:









In [13]:





%%R
data = lapply(column_names, get_column, plant_nodes)

plant_df = data.frame(data, stringsAsFactors = FALSE)

print(head(plant_df))

Packaging the gathering code into reusable functions¶










In [15]:





%%file ./script/plant_df-R

get_value  = function(plant_node, tag) xmlValue(plant_node[[tag]])
    
get_column = function(tag, plants) sapply(plants, get_value, tag)
    
create_df_from_plant_xml = function(plant_file){
    require(XML)
    xml_doc      = xmlParse(plant_file)
    root_node    = xmlRoot(xml_doc)
    plant_nodes  = xmlChildren(root_node)
    column_names = names(plant_nodes[[1]])

    data     = lapply(column_names, get_column, plant_nodes)
    return(data.frame(data, stringsAsFactors = FALSE))
}



















Writing ./script/plant_df-R


















Now, our function converting a raw plant XML file into a R data frame can be used in other notebooks, using the source command:









In [16]:





%%R
source('./script/plant_df-R')

print(head(create_df_from_plant_xml(plant_file)))
